newsitem.title: UK: Imperial Tobacco debut beats expectations.
newsitem.headline: Imperial Tobacco debut beats expectations.

text.p: Shares in Imperial Tobacco Plc made their market debut on Tuesday at above the expected price range, valuing the company at just above 2.0 billion pounds ($3.12 billion) after its spin-off from conglomerate Hanson Plc.
Imperial shares began trading at 390 pence, above expectations that it would start at between 370 and 380 pence.
Imperial Tobacco chief executive Gareth Davis said the issue had gone well.
"It seems to have gone well so far -- we've been watching the screens with great interest," Davis told Reuters from the offices of ABN AMRO Hoare Govett, stockbrokers to the company.
"We look forward to the rest of the day -- it will be interesting when the Americans come in," he said.
"So far so good, I think is the term. It's pretty early days yet," Davis said.

Asked whether he expected good demand from the U.S., Davis said a seven-city roadshow to make presentations to institutions there had met good interest. "There seemed to be a very high degree of interest -- we were pleasantly surprised."

Imperial, Britain's second-largest tobacco company, is the first Hanson company to be spun off in a demerger process that will split the Anglo-U.S. conglomerate, built up by Lord Hanson and the late Lord White, into four separate units.
The second to go, Millennium Chemicals, begins trading in New York on Wednesday.

In later morning trade, Imperial shares settled at around 392 pence. At the start of trading, they were briefly in backwardation, which is when the highest buy price quoted by a market maker is above the best sell price quoted by another. ($1=.6408 Pound)
